summary:
Marietje Kardaun (Maria Kardaun) is a senior lecturer at the Faculty of Arts and Social Sciences, Maastricht University, The Netherlands. She is in the Board of Editors of PSYART, a Hyperlink Journal for the Psychological Study of the Arts, member of the Netherlands Research School for Literary Studies, member of the Turmgruppe für Jung'sche Psychologie Zürich, and member of the Asociación de Psicología Analítica de Valencia. Studied Latin and Greek at Leiden University (1987, cum laude). Gained PhD in 1993 with a psychoanalytic (Freudian) interpretation of Petronius' Satyricon. Wrote a monograph on the concept of ‘mimesis’ in Greek philosophy for the Koninklijke Nederlandse Academie van Wetenschappen (Der Mimesisbegriff in der griechischen Antike, North-Holland 1993), and many articles of mainly Jungian literary criticism. Together with her colleague Joke Spruyt she edited The Winged Chariot: Collected Essays on Plato & Platonism in Honour of L.M. de Rijk, Leiden etc.: Brill 2000 (= Brill’s Studies in Intellectual History, vol. 100). In 2011 she published Fighting the Angel: Biblical and Mythical Encounters with Demons and Deities. Roskilde: EyeCorner (https://www.eyecorner.press/books/fighting-the-angel). Recurring themes in her work are: theoretical aspects of literary criticism; mythology; philosophy of art; Platonism; Romantic German poetry (Goethe, Herder, Eichendorff); depth psychological Bible interpretation; dreams in mythology and religion.
Marietje grew up in Overijssel, an eastern part of Holland. She is married to Jhr. Mr. Dr. Guus Röell, who started his career as an ethologist at the University of Groningen, subsequently worked as a criminologist at the University of Leiden and later at the Dutch Ministry of Justice in the Hague, and who is now an antiques dealer who specializes in Dutch colonial furniture (www.guusroell.com). Together with their son August (1998) and their heavily spotted stray dog Esau (2010) they live in Maastricht.
